title: Walmart Talk Lifts Litecoin Briefly
text:
The news release, purportedly from Walmart, claimed the retailer would allow customers to make payments with the cryptocurrency. Walmart shares fell 83 cents at $145.06.

"The press release is not authentic," said a Walmart spokeswoman. Walmart doesn't accept cryptocurrency as payment in the U.S., she said.

Litecoin creator Charlie Lee said the release wasn't connected to the cryptocurrency or the Litecoin Foundation, a nonprofit that manages it as a software project. "Yeah, it's fake," he said. "Don't know who created it."

The Litecoin Foundation's social-media manager was fooled by the fake release, Mr. Lee said, and retweeted it from the foundation's Twitter account.

"He thought it was real, too," he said. "It was wrong to retweet it. We deleted it quickly afterwards. But the damage is done."

Mr. Lee created litecoin in 2011 as an alternative to bitcoin, taking the latter's code and tweaking it to create a digital currency with lower fees and faster confirmation times.

It has been one of the more well-known cryptocurrencies but never grew into much more than a curiosity. With a market value of about $11.9 billion, litecoin is the 16th-largest cryptocurrency, according to CoinMarketCap.

GlobeNewswire issued a written statement that "journalists and other readers should disregard the news release."
